t: Job 30
“But*pn now they mock me, men*ld younger than I, whose*ln fathers I would have disdained to*ld put with my sheep dogs.
Of*ln what use was the strength of their hands to me, since*ld their vigor had gone from them?
Haggard*ln from want and hunger, they*ld roamed the parched land in*ld desolate wastelands at night.
In*ln the brush they gathered salt herbs, and*ld their food was the root of the broom bush.
They*ln were banished from human society, shouted*ld at as if they were thieves.
They*ln were forced to live in the dry stream beds, among*ld the rocks and in holes in the ground.
They*ln brayed among the bushes and*ld huddled in the undergrowth.
A*ln base and nameless brood, they*ld were driven out of the land.
“And*pn now those young men mock me in song; I*ld have become a byword among them.
They*ln detest me and keep their distance; they*ld do not hesitate to spit in my face.
Now*ln that God has unstrung my bow and afflicted me, they*ld throw off restraint in my presence.
On*ln my right the tribe attacks; they*ld lay snares for my feet, they*ld build their siege ramps against me.
They*ln break up my road; they*ld succeed in destroying me. ‘No*ld one can help him,’ they say.
They*ln advance as through a gaping breach; amid*ld the ruins they come rolling in.
Terrors*ln overwhelm me; my*ld dignity is driven away as by the wind, my*ld safety vanishes like a cloud.
“And*pn now my life ebbs away; days*ld of suffering grip me.
Night*ln pierces my bones; my*ld gnawing pains never rest.
In*ln his great power God becomes like clothing to me; he*ld binds me like the neck of my garment.
He*ln throws me into the mud, and*ld I am reduced to dust and ashes.
“I*pn cry out to you, God, but you do not answer; I*ld stand up, but you merely look at me.
You*ln turn on me ruthlessly; with*ld the might of your hand you attack me.
You*ln snatch me up and drive me before the wind; you*ld toss me about in the storm.
I*ln know you will bring me down to death, to*ld the place appointed for all the living.
“Surely*pn no one lays a hand on a broken man when*ld he cries for help in his distress.
Have*ln I not wept for those in trouble? Has*ld not my soul grieved for the poor?
Yet*ln when I hoped for good, evil came; when*ld I looked for light, then came darkness.
The*ln churning inside me never stops; days*ld of suffering confront me.
I*ln go about blackened, but not by the sun; I*ld stand up in the assembly and cry for help.
I*ln have become a brother of jackals, a*ld companion of owls.
My*ln skin grows black and peels; my*ld body burns with fever.
My*ln lyre is tuned to mourning, and*ld my pipe to the sound of wailing.
